pullRequest.bodyText: Adds a service file to work around the CDI.java SPI update clearing out the provider we set in AbstractCDIRuntime.start if CDI.current() is ever called in the context of a non-CDI app.

beforeCommit.message:
Adds a service loader reference to CDIRuntimeImpl (which implements CDIProvider)

This is nessacary because in a recent update CDI.java will clear the CDIProvider
set in AbstractCDIRuntime.start() if CDIProvider.getCDI() ever returns null and
later attempt to reacquire it through the service loader.

CDIProvider.getCDI() will return null if ever called from the context of a non
CDI app

nodes.bodyText:
This class does not need to be a Component as it's managed by ServiceLoader rather than as an OSGi service.
The Javadoc should also be improved to say it's a thin layer which looks up the real CDIProvider as an OSGi service.

This import is problematic.
There are cases where another feature might want to include the CDI API bundle, (or the CDI API feature) so that it can work with or without CDI present. I think this import will prevent the API bundle from resolving if the rest of CDI is not present.
I think the easiest way to do this would be to:

Add CDIProvider to the list of services provided by the CDIRuntimeImpl component
Remove all references to CDIRuntimeImpl and CDIService from CDIProviderService, just look up CDIProvider as a service instead
Move CDIProviderService into the API bundle.

If we didn't want to add non-API things to the API bundle, you could

Put the services file and CDIProviderService into a fragment which attaches to the API bundle
This would still require making the CDIRuntimeImpl component a CDIProvider service
